TRAMADOL HYDROCHLORIDE

OPIOIDS

  • Indications and doses
  • Pregnancy
  • Hepatic impairment
  • Renal impairment
  • Contra indications
  • Side effects
  • Administration
  • Patient and carer advice
  • Cautions
  • Prescribing and dispensing
  • Medicinal forms

Indications and doses

Moderate to severe pain,

By intramuscular injection or by intravenous injection or by intravenous infusion

  • For adults
    50–100 mg every 4–6 hours, intravenous injection to be given over 2–3 minutes.

Moderate to severe acute pain,

By mouth

  • For adults
    Initially 100 mg, then 50–100 mg every 4–6 hours; maximum 400 mg per day.
  • For children 12–17 years
    Initially 100 mg, then 50–100 mg every 4–6 hours; maximum 400 mg per day.

Moderate to severe chronic pain,

By mouth

  • For adults
    Initially 50 mg, then adjusted according to response to; maximum 400 mg per day.
  • For children 12–17 years
    Initially 50 mg, then adjusted according to response to; maximum 400 mg per day.

Postoperative pain,

By intravenous injection

  • For adults
    Initially 100 mg, then 50 mg every 10–20 minutes if required up to total maximum 250 mg (including initial dose) in first hour, then 50–100 mg every 4–6 hours, intravenous injection to be given over 2–3 minutes; maximum 600 mg per day.

Moderate to severe pain (with modified-release 12-hourly preparations),

By mouth using modified-release medicines

  • For adults
    50–100 mg twice daily, increased if necessary to 150–200 mg twice daily, maximum daily dose not usually required; maximum 400 mg per day.
  • For children 12–17 years
    50–100 mg twice daily, increased if necessary to 150–200 mg twice daily, maximum daily dose not usually required; maximum 400 mg per day.

Moderate to severe pain (with modified-release 24-hourly preparations),

By mouth using modified-release medicines

  • For adults
    Initially 100–150 mg once daily, increased if necessary up to 400 mg once daily.
  • For children 12–17 years
    Initially 100–150 mg once daily, increased if necessary up to 400 mg once daily.

Advice when patient is pregnant

Embryotoxic in animal studies—manufacturers advise avoid.

Advice regarding hepatic impairment

Caution (avoid for oral drops) in severe impairment.

Advice regarding renal impairment

Avoid use or reduce dose; opioid effects increased and prolonged and increased cerebral sensitivity occurs.

Caution (avoid for oral drops) in severe impairment.

Contra indications

  • Acute intoxication with alcohol
  • acute intoxication with analgesics
  • acute intoxication with hypnotics
  • acute intoxication with opioids
  • not suitable for narcotic withdrawal treatment
  • uncontrolled epilepsy

Known side effects

General side effects

commonOrVeryCommon: Malaise,

uncommon: Diarrhoea, flatulence, gastritis, retching,

rare: Abnormal coordination, anorexia, anxiety, bronchospasm, changes in appetite, delirium, dyspnoea, hypertension, muscle weakness, nightmares, paraesthesia, seizures, syncope, tremor, wheezing,

notKnown: Blood disorders, hypoglycaemia, speech disorders,

Directions for administration

Tramadol hydrochloride orodispersible tablets should be sucked and then swallowed. May also be dispersed in water.

Some tramadol hydrochloride modified-release capsule preparations may be opened and the content swallowed immediately without chewing—check individual preparations.

For intravenous infusion, dilute in Glucose 5% or Sodium Chloride 0.9%.

Advice for patients and carers

Patients or carers should be given advice on how to administer tramadol hydochloride orodispersible tablets.

In children

Medicines for Children leaflet: Tramadol for pain

www.medicinesforchildren.org.uk/tramadol-for-pain

Cautions regarding administration

  • Excessive bronchial secretions
  • history of epilepsy—use tramadol only if compelling reasons
  • impaired consciousness
  • not suitable as a substitute in opioid-dependent patients
  • not suitable in some types of general anaesthesia
  • susceptibility to seizures—use tramadol only if compelling reasons

  • Not recommended for analgesia during potentially light planes of general anaesthesia (possibly increased intra-operative recall reported).

Information regarding prescribing and dispensing

Do not confuse modified-release 12-hourly preparations with 24-hourly preparations.

Prepared medicinal forms of TRAMADOL HYDROCHLORIDE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Forms available from special-order manufacturers include: oral suspension,
Soluble tablet
Orodispersible tablet
Modified-release tablet
Capsule
Modified-release capsule
Oral drops
Solution for injection
